job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cape Girardeau, MO
pros: Constantly looking to improve efficiency. Financially sound and pay/comp is better than most area institutions.
cons: Improvements often made at the expense of employees and/or patients due to metrics driving decisions. This is not a problem unique to this one healthcare system, but the cross town option that is often used for comparison still utilizes traditional values of patient care over profits. Additionally, every position in the hospital feels micromanaged from having to interview with the CEO as a new employee to having to do a daily checklist for menial tasks. Multiple daily meetings meetings prevent actual work from getting done. There is no sense of community not any reason to do more than what is minimally expected do to progressive policies.

job_title: Patient Transporter in Cape Girardeau, MO
pros: I love my co workers and managers dearly. Every position starts at no less than $12 an hour
cons:
Morale is pretty bad. Upper management tries to fix it with special days such as Ice cream days and free drive in movies which while nice, most of us would like to be paid more instead. 
Also, Some departments have the bare minimum help. My department would rather have more workers and more downtime to rest than get a raise even.
Patient Transport is an incredibly physical job. Be prepared to push heavy beds for 10-15 miles a day. This is not an exageration.

job_title: Anonymous in Cape Girardeau, MO
pros: Decent pay and benefits compared to other facilities in the area, very nice main campus. Employee discount on SFMC health services. I gained a lot of useful experience that has served me well at my new, better job.
cons: High turnover, incompetent supervisors and managers that know nothing about the department they’re managing. “Favorite” employees given clearly preferential treatment over others. Resistant to employee input and suggestions. Constant push to work faster and harder with fewer and fewer staff and resources. Upper management cares far more about their reputation in the community than their own employees. The CEO has said verbatim “it’s my job to make sure you’re engaged, not that you’re happy.” Which may well be true, but employee satisfaction goes a long way towards reducing turnover rates.

job_title: Systems Engineer in Cape Girardeau, MO
pros: Co-Workers / Peers are amazing. Extremely talented and smart, and extremely good at reacting to the chaos from management regarding poorly (or just plan not...) planned projects.
cons:
Massive Turnover of Leadership, especially IT Leadership. I'd had 4x CIOs and 5x Bosses in 3 years. The HR Department has not had a Director for more than 6 months in the last 2 years. 

No long term vision for the company / department: They just buy clinic after clinic while cutting open FTEs, forcing ever increasing workloads of anyone that departs onto their peers. 

You honestly won't know what work you'll be doing in 3 months because they don't know themselves.

The way both the Administration treats, and allows Physicians to treat, the general staff is horrifying. I've heard recorded phone calls of Surgeons threatening to get Help Desk staff fired for just asking troubleshooting questions. I've had Nurses tell me stories of Physicians threatening to kill them. That's not hyperbolic, they really threatened them and when they brought it up to HR, they were moved into a different department; No corrective action for the Doctor who threatened them.
